Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 10:33PM LoriG wrote: I agree that going to a breast center is ideal.  I didn't "have" to, but I did bring my films, reports, etc. from one appointment to another.  Before I did that, I had some films MIA that have never been found.  When they want to do a comparison, sometimes seeing the films is more important than reading the reports.  I am not nasty about my comments, questions and suggestions, but I do tell them that I have to be my own advocate and make sure my mind is at ease.  Good luck with your future appointments...you are on the right track doing all of the right things!  Lori
Posts.Title: question about providers Gemini16 jerseymaria

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2007 05:13AM LoriG wrote: If your letter writng campaign doesn't work, I'd also consider writing to one of your local television stations (especially if you have one in your area that deals with helping out consumers). They love to take on big business like the insurance industry and the insurance company usually doesn't like the negative publicity. Keep a copy of everything (keep the letters cordial) and see what happens. Good luck! Lori

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2007 09:54AM LoriG wrote: Imagine living this in front of millions and millions of people. I am sure the things we say could annoy others without us meaning to and we are not speaking live on camera to millions of people. Robin is trying to do the right thing by going public and putting a face on breast cancer. She is trying to speak volumes in a short period of time especially as it comes to early detection which is the key. She looked so scared but tried to put on a brave face. We all wish her well on her surgery on Friday and any further treatment she will have. I hope she comes here under an assumed name so she can receive the annonymous help she will want to seek. God bless you, Robin. God bless all of us! Lori

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2007 10:59AM LoriG wrote: A good friend of mine is a receptionist at a doctor's office and she will say that reports are not available because the doctor is not there because she said people will cry, get angry and yell and do everything they can to try to get her to read the report to them over the phone. She said that she has a heart and it hurts when she has to say "no" to someone who is crying on the phone for information, but she could lose her job if she helps them; she said to be easier on her and be sure she keeps her job, she just tells them the report is not there until the doctor is available to speak with the patient. Lori

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 01:51PM LoriG wrote: I never enjoyed camping (my idea of roughing it is going to a four star hotel) but my younger brother loves to tent camp.  Before he went to basic training for the army, he wanted one last family hurrah before he shipped out with the whole family.  No running water, no bathrooms except for the tree next to the campsite and cooking over an open fire.  I got stung by chiggars so bad I had to go to the doctor for oral medication.  My air mattress sprung a leak that we couldn't find (the leak that is) and I layed on a rock that was under the tent that we pitched without realizing it was there.  We all got sick from something we ate and most of us threw up the last half of the weekend.  I kinda have a bad taste in my mouth (literally and figuratively) from camping!  Lori

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 04:23PM LoriG wrote: Be careful about reading too much information online.  It may confuse and upset you because all of a sudden, you can have the same symptoms you are reading about.  Be informed enough to ask the right questions at your appointments, but be careful about reading all of the gloom and doom on the web.  Good luck with your appointment!  Lori
